titleStmt.title: Target gene expression studies on Platynereis dumerilii and Platynereis cfr massiliensis at the shallow CO 2 vents off Ischia, Italy

analytic.title: Target gene expression studies on Platynereis dumerilii and Platynereis cfr massiliensis at the shallow CO 2 vents off Ischia, Italy

biblStruct.note: Received Date: 28 October 2016 Revised Date: 3 November 2017 Accepted Date: 12 November 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Coastal and Shelf Science Ocean acidification

abstract.p: Many studies predict negative effects of ocean acidification on marine organisms, potentially leading to loss of biodiversity and ecosystem function. Research on species inhabiting naturally high pCO 2 environments, such as volcanic CO vents, offers an opportunity to understand the molecular mechanisms involved in high pCO 2 regulation. Here we investigate the relative expression of NADH dehydrogenase, sodium-hydrogen antiporter (NHE), carbonic anhydrase (CA) and paramyosin genes from two non-calcifying sibling Nereididae polychaetes species, Platynereis cfr massiliensis, collected in the shallow CO 2 vents off Ischia (Italy; 40°43'52.0"N 13°57'46.2"E and 40°43'55.5"N 13°57'48.4"E), and P. dumerilii collected in an area nearby (40°43'34.51''N; 13°57'35.7''E). The origin of the worms was confirmed using restriction enzyme digest. NHE and paramyosin expressions were both significantly increased in P. dumerilii relative to the P. cfr massiliensis vent populations.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Since the Industrial revolution, atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) levels have increased from 280 ppm in pre-industrial times to over 380 ppm, contributing to ocean acidification (OA), also termed the 'other CO 2 problem' (IPCC 2013). Over the last decade, OA has become the focus of numerous studies examining the effects of changing seawater conditions on marine organisms (Gattuso and Hansson 2011). From pre-industrial times to the 1990s, the ocean surface mean pH has decreased from 8.2 to 8.07 and models predict a further pH drop by 0.4 pH units by the year 2100 (Caldeira and Wickett 2003;Gattuso and Lavigne 2009). To predict the impact of OA on organisms, it is essential to understand its effects on molecular processes that form the basis of physiological functions.

Several transcriptomic and proteomic studies have been conducted in which marine organisms have been exposed to experimental OA conditions. The majority of these studies focus on differential expression in calcifying organisms such as sea urchins, corals, barnacles, oysters and coccolithophores (Todgham and Hofmann 2009;O'Donnell et al. 2010;Martin et al. 2011;Parker et al. 2011;Stumpp et al. 2011;Tomanek et al. 2011;Wong et al. 2011;Dineshram et al. 2012;Moya et al. 2012;Dineshram et al. 2013;Jones et al. 2013;Pespeni et al. 2013;Vidal-Dupiol et al. 2013). These studies reveal that genes involved in biomineralisation, lipid/energy metabolism, acid-base regulation and ion transport processes M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 3 exhibit the most significant changes in gene expression patterns in response to OA (O'Donnell et al. 2010;Dineshram et al. 2012;Moya et al. 2012;Pespeni et al. 2013;Vidal-Dupiol et al. 2013;Wong et al. 2011).

The genus Platynereis comprises non-calcifying worms that are abundant off Ischia Island (Italy) in the Mediterranean Sea, including natural CO vents (Ricevuto et al. 2014;Gambi et al. 2016). Based on reciprocal transplant experiments and genetic examinations, Calosi et al. (2013) concluded that the vent-inhabiting lineages of P. dumerilii are genetically and physiologically adapted to the high pCO 2 conditions. The genetic distances between the vent-inhabiting lineages and those from nearby non-acidified control locations suggest that they potentially represent a sibling species (Calosi et al. 2013). Lucey et al. (2015) observed egg brooding in individuals collected from the vent and reproducing in lab conditions, suggests that these vent-inhabiting worms may be P. massiliensis (Moquin-Tandon 1869), a sibling species that is morphologically identical to P. dumerilii, but with differing reproductive strategies and life history (Hauenschild 1951;Schneider et al. 1992;Helm et al. 2014).

Volcanic CO -vents haven been described as a useful system, with a very high ecological relevance, to investigate long-term effects of OA on benthic biota and sea-floor ecosystems (Hall-Spencer et al. 2008;Fabricius et al. 2011;Gattuso et al. 2014). Several studies have focused on polychaetes at the Ischia Castello Aragonese CO 2 vents including: settlement of benthic invertebrates (Ricevuto et al. 2012), ecosystem responses along the pH gradient (Kroeker et al. 2011), colonisation of selected polychaete species (Ricevuto et al. 2014), and adaptation and acclimation in marine ectotherms (Calosi et al. 2013). Here, we examine gene expression changes, of a selected number of genes representing energy metabolism (NADH dehydrogenase), acid-base regulation (sodium-hydrogen antiporter (NHE) and carbonic anhydrase (CA)) and cytoskeleton processes (paramyosin), of the two
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 4
div.p: sibling species, P. dumerilii, collected near the CO 2 vent off Ischia, and P. cfr massiliensis (origin determined via restriction enzyme digest), collected inside the CO 2 vents, as well as after a 7 day low/ high pH laboratory exposure experiment. The present study focuses on the hypothesis that worms living inside vents are adapted to high CO 2 conditions and will respond differently, in terms of specific gene expressions, compared to those inhabiting outside the vent. This will thus provide further insights into the cellular mechanisms affected by pCO 2 changes.

div.head: Animal collection
div.p: Benthic adult stages of P. cfr massiliensis were collected from CO 2 vent sites (Castello Aragonese) and benthic adult stages of P. dumerilii were collected from a non-acidified site, both located at the north-east side off the island of Ischia (Tyrrhenian Sea, Italy). Collection was performed in June 2014 by snorkelling at 1-2 m depth. P. cfr massiliensis were collected in the rocky reef and dead Posidonia oceanica seagrass matte covered with macroalgae on the south and north sides of the Castello Aragonese of the Ischia CO 2 vent areas, defined as stations Castello S2/S3 (40°43'52.0"N 13°57'46.2"E) and Castello N3 (40°43'55.5"N 13°57'48.4"E) in previous work (e.g. Donnarumma et al. 2014;Ricevuto et al. 2014). The area is characterised by a pH range between 6.6 and 7.8 (Kroeker et al. 2011). Seawater physico-chemical parameters have been previously measured by Ricevuto et al. (2015a) and report on the following means ± s.d.: Castello S2/S3: TA 2597.4 ± 75.3 µequiv kg -1 , pCO 2 4266.2 ± 2814.1 µatm, HCO 3 -2518.9 ± 101.4 µmol kg -1 SW, CO 2-31.0 ± 40.1 µmol kg -1 SW, T 19.0 ± 1.2 °C, Salinity 37.2 ± 0.6 and Castello N3: TA 2606.7 ± 82.1 µequiv kg -1 , pCO 2 2546.0 ± 2548.5 µatm, HCO -2495.2 ± 100.2 µmol kg -1 SW, CO 2-44.0 ± 39.7 µmol kg -1 SW, T 19.0 ± 1.3 °C, Salinity 37.1 ± 0.8. P. dumerilii were collected, in the same way as P. cfr massiliensis, from a sampling site with ambient pCO 2 conditions, at the north-east side
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: off the island Ischia (Tyrrhenian Sea, Italy), named 'S. Anna', approximately 600 m away from the south side vent area of Castello (40°43'34.51''N;13°57'35.7''E) ( Fig. 1). Venting activities are absent in this area and pH values represent ambient conditions (mean pH ± s.d.
8.07±0.002; for detailed water chemistry see Ricevuto et al. 2015b).
Worms were collected by detaching thalli of macroalgae (mainly of the brown algae,

Halopteris scoparia and Dictyota dichotoma) and inserting them quickly inside of fabric bags (20 cm x 20 cm). The bags were kept in a cooler with water from the collecting site, and were transported to the laboratory located approximately 4 km from the Castello vent area (Villa Dohrn-Benthic ecology Centre, Ischia). The algae were subsequently transferred to a large plastic tray and gently shaken. Atokous worms (segment number: >40) were then transferred
into Petri dishes and worms in a sexually immature stage were selected for the gene expression analysis. This was to avoid expression differences based on reproductive changes.
The wet weight of all the worms was determined with a precision balance (Mettler AT200).

A number of worms from each site were transferred immediately into individual Eppendorf tubes with RNALater solution (Sigma-Aldrich Company Ltd., Gillingham, U.K.) (Castello N3 n=21; Castello S2/S3 n=25; S. Anna n=15). The remaining worms were used for a 7-day laboratory exposure experiment in controlled conditions.

div.head: Laboratory exposure experiments
div.p: For the laboratory exposure regime, worms were kept in covered glass bowls ( were kept at their original seawater pH/ pCO 2 (pH ~8.00), measured at the sampling site off Ischia Island, as a control group ('non-acidified C-C') and another 24 worms were exposed to
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 6
div.p: low pH (~7.7) (now referred to as 'acidified C-A'). The same procedure was followed with 40 specimens (P. cfr massiliensis) collected in the acidified area Castello S2/S3. 20 worms were kept in acidified conditions (pH ~7.7) ('acidified A-A') and 20 worms were kept under ambient pH conditions (pH ~8.00) (now referred to as 'non-acidified A-C') as treatment.

For both exposure experiments the pH of the water was measured every day (Table 1) with a Mettler portable pH-meter (precision level 0.01 pH). The water with the required pH was prepared every day by bubbling CO 2 into the seawater (KitCO 2 Energy professional, Ferplast
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

div.head: Target gene isolation and characterisation
div.p: Target genes were selected based on previous studies (Wäge et al. 2015; and using MIQE Guidelines (Bustin et al. 2009). The present work utilised two established reference genes with different roles in cellular processes: 18S, involved in ribosomal structure and α-TUB, taking part in cytoskeletal structure. 18S has previously been established as a reference gene for Nereis species (Won et al., 2011;Zheng et al., 2011 Wäge et al. (2015Wäge et al. ( , 2016. with a final extension of 72 °C for 2 min. For the generation of a melt curve, a heating step for 5 sec at 60˚C and 5 sec at 95˚C was added to the end of the PCR run. In order to verify the specificity of the amplified products the melting curve, gel picture and sequences were analysed. The amplification efficiency of each primer pair was validated by a dilution series of cDNA. The crossing point (Cp) for each target mRNA was detected and normalised to the reference genes α-TUB, and 18S rRNA (Zheng et al. 2011;Won et al. 2011). For this the 2 -∆∆CT (LivaK) method was used (Livak and Schmittgen 2001).
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

div.head: Restriction enzyme analysis
div.p: Phylogenetic analysis based on cytochrome c oxidase subunit I (COI) has shown that worms from the vent sampling site Castello S3 are genetically different to P. dumerilii from the control site S. Anna (Calosi et al. 2013). These published COI sequences were used to find nucleotide differences between the two populations (see supplementary material, Fig. 1), and utilised to develop an enzyme restriction (BstZ17I) digest to confirm worms were vent populations rather than worms that had travelled into that area. For the digest, 5 µl of COI
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: PCR product, µl (10 u) restriction enzyme and 2 µl of the corresponding 1× Buffer 0 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Loughborough, U.K.) were mixed and incubated at 37°C for 3 hours. The restriction digested PCR products were analysed on a 1% agarose gel, stained with SYBR Safe DNA gel stain (see supplementary material, Fig. 2) (Life Technologies, Paisley, U.K.). (Castello S2/S3) worms (P. cfr massiliensis), yet no significant difference (p=0.674) was observed between S. Anna and the Castello N3 vent individuals (P. cfr massiliensis) (Fig. 2).

div.head: Statistical analyses
div.p: The NADH dehydrogenase mRNA expression in P. cfr massiliensis worms sampled at the Castello S2/S3 vent areas was significantly higher (p=0.002) in comparison to those sampled at the Castello N3 vent (P. cfr massiliensis) (Fig. 2).

NHE: NHE mRNA expression was significantly increased (p<0.001) in worms collected at S. Anna (P. dumerilii), in comparison to individuals from the vent sites Castello S2/S3 and Castello N3 (P. cfr massiliensis). No significant difference (p=0.117) was detected between the two vent populations collected in the acidified areas S2/S3 and N3 ( Fig. 3).

div.head: CA:
div.p: The primers designed for CA failed to amplify using worms from S. Anna and most Castello N3, therefore, only the gene expression of a small sample number of Castello N3

and S2/S3 were analysed. No significant gene expression differences of CA on any of the field populations could be detected, however a trend for a lower expression in Castello S2/S3 could be observed (Kruskal-Wallis, p= 0.051) ( Fig. 4).
Paramyosin: Paramyosin mRNA expression was significantly higher in P. dumerilii worms from S. Anna in comparison to P. cfr massiliensis from both Castello S2/S3 (p=0.015) and
Castello N3 (p<0.001). There was no significant difference between Castello N3 and Castello S2/S3 (p=0.054) ( Fig. 5).

div.head: Relative target gene expressions in transplant experiment worms
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 11
div.p: NADH dehydrogenase: P. cfr massiliensis from Castello S2/S3 (A-C) showed a significant down regulation (p=0.017) of NADH dehydrogenase in comparison to Castello S2/S3 kept at low pH (7.7; A-A) for 7 d. In contrast, the worms from S. Anna (P. dumerilii), which were transferred from ambient to low pH conditions (C-A), showed no significant (p=0.535) gene expression difference in NADH dehydrogenase after 7 d (Fig. 2). No significant effect on the relative gene expression of NADH dehydrogenase could be observed when comparing individuals from S. Anna in the 7 d transfer experiment to the field collected worms from S.

Anna (C-C: p=0.319; C-A: p=0.642). The worms collected at the vent site Castello S2/S3 showed no significant difference of the relative NADH dehydrogenase expression to the worms used in the transfer experiment (A-A: p=0.397; A-C: p=0.309) (Fig. 2).

div.head: NHE:
div.p: The 7 d low pH exposure (C-A) of worms sampled from S. Anna showed no significant effect (p=0.229) on the relative gene expression of NHE in comparison to the control group (C-C) (Fig. 3). Comparing the expression of NHE from worms of the laboratory experiment (C-C and C-A) to the worms sampled straight from the field (S. Anna), no difference could be detected (C-C: p= 0.782; C-A: p= 0.250). In contrast to P. dumerilii from S. Anna, the P. cfr massiliensis specimens from Castello S2/S3 that were transferred to ambient pH (8.0; A-C) showed a significant (p=0.017) down regulation in NHE in comparison to Castello S2/S3 kept at low pH (7.7; A-A). Comparing Castello S2/S3 worms from the transfer experiment (A-A and A-C) with Castello S2/S3 (field observation) a significant down-regulation in NHE can be observed (A-A: p<0.001; A-C: p<0.001) (Fig. 3).

div.head: CA:
div.p: The relative gene expression of CA of worms from Castello S2/S3, which were transferred to ambient pH (A-C), showed no significant change (Fig. 4).

div.head: Paramyosin:
div.p: The relative gene expression of paramyosin of P. dumerilii from S. Anna transferred to low pH (7.7; C-A) for 7 d showed no significant (p=0.528) difference to worms kept at ambient pH (8.0; C-C). However, comparing the S. Anna worms collected in the field
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: with the two groups kept in the laboratory experiment (S. Anna C-C and C-A) a significant down-regulation of paramyosin (C-C: p<0.001; C-A: p<0.001) was observed.

P. cfr massiliensis from Castello S2/S3 transferred from vent conditions into ambient pH conditions (A-C) showed no significant difference (p=0.275) in the relative gene expression of paramyosin (Fig. 5) in comparison to the group kept at acidified conditions (A-A). The transfer to the laboratory showed a significant down-regulation in comparison to the field samples of Castello S2/S3 (A-A: p<0.001; A-C: p<0.001).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The present study used a targeted approach to investigate a selected number of genes involved in energy metabolism (NADH dehydrogenase), transport of CO 2 in the blood (CA), ion exchange and transport (NHE) and cytoskeleton function (paramyosin) to examine cellular mechanistic effects of pCO 2 changes in two closely related sibling polychaete species. Here, we showed that the target genes, NADH dehydrogenase, NHE and paramyosin, are significantly differentially regulated in adult, atokus P. cfr massiliensis residing in naturally low pH environments compared to the sibling species P. dumerilii living in nearby ambient conditions. In contrast, only NADH dehydrogenase was significantly different between the two vent populations (P. cfr massiliensis) collected on the south (S2/S3) and north (N3) sides of the Castello area of Ischia, Italy. NADH dehydrogenase is involved in the mitochondrial electron transport chain and therefore indirectly in generating ATP (Weiss et al. 1991). The relative gene expression encoding for NADH dehydrogenase in the Castello N3 vent worms was significantly down-regulated in comparison to the Castello S3 individuals (Fig. 2). A possible explanation for this could be the locations of the vents. It is known that gene expression levels can be affected by both genomic and environmental factors, such as light, temperature and stress. These factors can cause changes in hormone

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: and enzymatic reactions, which subsequently influences the expression levels of different genes (Tastan et al. 2005). The north vent of Ischia is much more exposed to wind, waves and shade than the sunny, sheltered south vent side (Ricevuto et al. 2014;2015b), and could therefore effect the gene expression of the worms in a different way. NADH dehydrogenase showed significantly lower levels of mRNA expression in worms sampled from S. Anna compared to worms from the vent site Castello S2/S3 (Fig. 2). This result is consistent with results from a study that looked at the metabolic rate (MO ) in vent and non-vent worms at

Ischia (Calosi et al. 2013). These authors reported that the metabolic rate in vent specimens is constantly maintained at higher levels. Living under acidified conditions is potentially energetically costly, for instance to maintain physiological regulations such as intracellular pH homeostasis. Therefore, the overall energy demand is likely to be higher in vent worms. Calosi et al. (2013) suggested that the MO 2 is potentially higher in order to compensate for chronic pCO 2 -induced hypoxaemia. A study on the brittlestar, Ophiura ophiura, reported similar findings, with an up-regulation in the metabolism under low pH treatments (pH 7.3) and low temperature (Wood et al. 2010). Widdicombe and Spicer (2008) predicted that there is a trade-off between metabolism and cost elsewhere, such as growth. In contrast to Calosi et al. (2013) no significant difference in the wet weight, between the two vent populations and the non-vent population (see supplementary material Fig. 3), was observed, but this may be due to patchiness when sampling from a mixture of macroalgae and seagrass (Ricevuto et al. 2014) or to seasonal differences. The transfer of worms from S. Anna (C-C) to high pCO 2 conditions (C-A) showed no significant effect on the gene expression of NADH dehydrogenase (Fig. 2), which indicated that P. dumerilii maintained their pre exposure metabolic condition. This is in line with the work of Calosi et al. (2013) who reported no significant difference in the mean MO 2 of P. dumerilii collected in normal pH conditions outside the vent exposed to elevated pCO 2 / low pH conditions within the vents. In contrast,

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: 14 during the transfer of P. cfr massiliensis from Castello S2/S3 to lower pCO 2 conditions (A-C) a significant down regulation of NADH dehydrogenase was observed (Fig. 2). A possible explanation could be that the pH change of the water leads to a metabolic reduction i.e. less energy is needed to maintain internal pH under lower pCO 2 conditions. This is supported by the NHE expression ( Fig. 3) whereby the transfer of worms from Castello S2/S3 to normal pCO 2 conditions (A-C) led to a significant down regulation of the acid-base transporter. The relative gene expression of NHE in worms collected at S. Anna is increased relative to both vent populations. This could be explained by the metabolic expense of the NHE, which is considered as a particularly costly antiporter (Pörtner et al. 2000). Living in extreme environmental conditions, such as CO 2 vents, already bears a significant cost, likely explaining the lower expression of this antiporter in vent populations.

In contrast to NADH dehydrogenase and NHE, the primers designed for CA, a zinccontaining enzyme that catalyses the hydration of CO 2 to HCO - (Tripp et al., 2001), failed to amplify using worms from S. Anna and most of the Castello N3 worms. This supports the theory of Calosi et al. (2013) that these two sibling species are physiologically more different than their morphologically identical appearance indicates. The primers do not appear to be specific enough to amplify the template, which resulted either in mispriming or no amplification of the target. This may be due to differences in the third codon position which will not affect the amino acid sequence but the function of the primer. The gene expression of CA did not show a significant change in the different vent populations and in the transfer experiment (Fig. 4). However, the transfer of worms from Castello S3 to ambient pH conditions showed a down-regulation trend in the relative gene expression of CA. mercenaria, which were exposed to high pCO 2 . In calcifying species CA is important for the shell calcification process, but like in other species also for the cellular homeostasis. The down-regulation trend in the present experiment suggests that due to the lower concentrations of CO 2 in the seawater the need of the enzyme to facilitate gas exchange and CO 2 excretion is reduced. This might be a way for the polychaete to use their metabolic capacity in an efficient way.

A significant up-regulation of paramyosin gene expression in P. dumerilii collected at S. Anna compared to the two vent populations (Castello N3 and S2/S3) was observed (Fig. 5). Furthermore, the transfer to the laboratory led to a down-regulation of paramyosin in both S. Anna and Castello S2/S3 individuals, indicating a stress response potentially induced through the transport and changing environment (Fig. 5). Paramyosin, which is involved in muscle contraction and immunoregulation (Gobert et al. 2005), increases with the length of thick filaments, improves muscle stability and increases muscle force (Hooper et al. 2008).

The synthesis of paramyosin is potentially energetically costly and could be reduced under extreme environmental conditions. Broadcast spawning in P. dumerilii is based on an energetically very costly metamorphosis into the epitokous heteronereis (Hauenschild and Fischer 1969). Paramyosin could potentially play an indirect role in the upkeep of muscle contraction essential during the reproduction process of fast swimming and spawning of gametes. Shallow water, high CO 2 vents have been used in many studies to look at potential ecological and evolutionary impacts of OA (Calosi et al. 2013;Hall-Spencer et al. 2008;Donnarumma et al. 2014). Especially, polychaetes have been investigated with regards to low pH effects (Kroeker et al. 2011, Ricevuto et al. 2014, Gambi et al. 2016. However Table Legends Table 1. Seawater pH (mean ± SEM) in Platynereis holding glass bowls during 7-day exposure experiment. Table 2. Real-time PCR primer sequences including amplicon size in base pairs (bp) and concentrations used for qPCR.

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: A C C E P T E D

figure.figDesc: target gene expressions in field collected worms NADH dehydrogenase: The relative gene expression of NADH dehydrogenase was significantly lower (p<0.001) in S. Anna worms (P. dumerilii) in comparison to vent

A study on the coral species Pocillopora damicornis found a significant up-regulation at pH 7.8 and 7.4 , after an exposure time of 3 weeks (Vidal-Dupiol et al. 2013). The study by Ivanina et al. (2013) also detected an increase of CA in the bivalves Crassostrea virginica and Mercenaria

, a disadvantage of natural vent systems is that vents are usually small, open systems enablingmobile species such as polychaetes to move in and out. As such, it is unclear, whether individuals found at a vent at a particular time spend their entire life in such low pH sustain key functional traits including feeding and reproduction under normal seawater conditions near to, but outside a vent. Collecting specimens in a vent does therefore not guarantee that this individual is a long-term resident of this extreme environment potentially biasing physiological and ecological studies undertaken with those individuals(Calosi et al., 2013). The present work included an investigation of the origin of all sampled individuals (vent type or not). The digestion of the COI PCR products of each individual with BstZ17I showed that 4.8 % of the worms collected inside the vents were not from the vent populations. As vents are open systems enabling species to migrate between CO 2 stress and normal water condition sites in the area, the important aspect of residence time of individuals populations and their connectivity with other not-acidified ecosystems, need to be better addressed in future studies to understand eco-physiological effects of OA.The present study shows that the relative gene expression between individuals collected from vents and nearby differs. The transfer experiments of atokous P. dumerilii did not show expression changes in any of the selected genes, which indicates that the worms may be relatively tolerant towards pH changes. However, further experiments are needed to see how other genes are affected and also if the sampling time point has an influence on the gene expression, as many environmental factor can have an influence on the gene expression.Additionally it is important for experiments to identify the origin of the specimens as individuals collected inside the vents might be from a population from outside the vent. The digestion of the COI PCR product with the restriction enzyme BstZ17I is a quick and easy way to test this, as presented in this study. Overall the present gene expression study helps to gain further insights into the cellular mechanisms affected by pCO 2 of the study and coordinated and helped to draft the manuscript. JMR participated in the design of the study and advised the molecular work.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Map of the sampling site in Italy on the island Ischia around Castello Aragonese and the S. Anna islets.

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Normalised average relative mRNA transcription ± standard error of the mean in Platynereis for NADH dehydrogenase in field populations (S. Anna, Castello S2/S3, Castello N3) and after 1 week in sea water with pH 8.0 (CC and AC) and pH 7.7 (CA, AA). Analysis was performed using the Kruskall-Wallis test (p < 0.05). In case of significance a Mann-Whitney U test was used to evaluate significance. For all analyses, statistical significance was accepted at p<0.05. Significant effects are labelled with letters. Only letters with the same colour (black, blue or red) were compared in the Mann-Whitney U test with each other.

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Normalised average relative mRNA transcription ± standard error of the mean in Platynereis for Sodium hydrogen antiporter in field populations (S. Anna, Castello S2/S3, Castello N3) and after 1 week in sea water with pH 8.0 (CC, control and AC, treatment) and pH 7.7 (CA, treatment and AA, control). Analysis was performed by nonparametric Kruskall-Wallis test (p < 0.05). In case of significance a Mann-Whitney U test was used to evaluate significance. For all analyses, statistical significance was accepted at p<0.05. Significant effects are labelled with letters. Only letters with the same colour (black, blue or red) were M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D compared in the Mann-Whitney U test with each other. The y-axis is presented in logarithmic scale in base 10.

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: Normalised average relative mRNA transcription ± standard error of the mean in Platynereis for Carbonic anhydrase in field populations (Castello S2/S3, Castello N3) and after 1 week in sea water with pH 8.0 (AC, treatment) and pH 7.7 (AA, control). Analysis was performed by nonparametric Kruskall-Wallis test (p < 0.05). P-value of Kruskal-Wallis test p= 0.051.

figure.head: Figure 5 .
figure.figDesc: Normalised average relative mRNA transcription ± standard error of the mean in Platynereis for Paramyosin in field populations (S. Anna, Castello S2/S3, Castello N3) and after 1 week in sea water with pH 8.0 (CC, control and AC, treatment) and pH 7.7 (CA, treatment and AA, control). Analysis was performed by nonparametric Kruskall-Wallis test (p < 0.05). In case of significance a Mann-Whitney U test was used to evaluate significance. For all analyses, statistical significance was accepted at p<0.05. Significant effects are labelled with letters. Only letters with the same colour (black, blue or red) were compared in the Mann-Whitney U test with each other.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Alignment of selected S. Anna and Castello S3 cytochrome c oxidase subunit I from GenBank. Regions showing homology are indicated by an asterisk. Grey shaded region shows restriction site for BstZ17I in Castello S3. Red arrow indicates cutting position.GenBank accession numbers for sequences are: S3_10 (KC591836.1), S3_8 (KC591834.1

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: 1% agarose-gel of BstZ17I digested COI PCR products from Castello S2/S3 and N3 worms used in qPCR analysis. A 100 bp ladder (L) (New England Biolabs, Hitchin, U.K.) was run to the right of each well raw.

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Body mass (wet weight) of Platynereis collected from S. Anna in low pCO 2 environment and within the two CO vents (Castello S2/S3 and N3) with elevated pCO 2 conditions.

figure.head: Genetic characterisation of the worms sampled in the vent sites.
figure.figDesc: Statistical analyses were performed using Minitab 16 (Minitab Inc., State College, PA). Since normality (Shapiro-Wilk) and independence assumption were not fulfilled and log transformation, to make the data conform more closely to normal distribution, was not successful, the significant variations in gene expression levels were determined using the nonparametric Kruskall-Wallis test (p < 0.05). In case of significance a Mann-Whitney U test was used to evaluate significant differences between data. For all analyses, statistical significance was accepted at p<0.05. Significant effects are labelled with letters. Values are presented as means ± SE. All graphs were designed with XACT 8.03 (SciLab, Germany).Restriction enzyme digest of COI amplicons of worms from the vent sampling sites revealed that 95.2 % of the Platynereis collected in the CO 2 vent sampling sites, Castello S2/S3 and N3, belong to the vent population. For the subsequent gene expression analysis, only specimens belonging to P. cfr massiliensis were used for the CO 2 vent groups. Data on body mass for each sampling group is reported in the supplementary material figure 3.

body.note: ng of total RNA and following the manufacturer's protocol. Any remaining RNA template was removed using an RNase H digest (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Loughborough, U.K.) in a 45 min, 37 °C incubation.
